name: Helsinki
fun_fact: Fun fact: Finland has over 3.3 million saunas for a population of 5.5 million people - nearly one sauna per person! Finnish sauna culture is so integral to life that it was inscribed on UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage List in 2020, and almost 90% of Finns take a sauna once a week (traditionally on Saturday night).

hero_dishes.name: Karjalanpiirakka (Karelian Pie)
hero_dishes.description: One of Finland's most beloved savory pastries - a thin rye crust filled with rice porridge, traditionally topped with munavoi (egg butter)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originating from the Karelia region, this dish has been made since the 13th century and earned EU Traditional Speciality Guaranteed (TSG) status. The egg butter topping is made by mixing hard-boiled eggs with butter.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Caf√© Regatta, Old Market Hall, local bakeries throughout Helsinki. Best enjoyed with coffee during the afternoon kahvitauko (coffee break).

hero_dishes.name: Lohikeitto (Salmon Soup)
hero_dishes.description: The ultimate Finnish comfort food - creamy soup with chunks of salmon, potatoes, carrots, leeks, and dill
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born from Finland's rich fishing traditions and long winters requiring warming, nourishing meals. The creaminess comes from a touch of cream and milk.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: L√∂yly (famous sauna-restaurant on the waterfront), Lappi, traditional Finnish restaurants. Often served with dark rye bread.

hero_dishes.name: Poronk√§ristys (Saut√©ed Reindeer)
hero_dishes.description: Thin slices of reindeer meat slowly saut√©ed with onions, butter, and often a splash of beer or stock
hero_dishes.origin_story: An iconic dish from northern Finland (Lapland) representing the indigenous S√°mi culture and the importance of reindeer herding. The meat becomes incredibly tender through slow cooking.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurant Lappi (authentic Lappish atmosphere), Konstan M√∂lj√§. Always served with mashed potatoes and lingonberry jam.

hero_dishes.name: Hernekeitto (Pea Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Creamy pea soup slow-cooked with pork until rich and smoky
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditionally eaten on Thursdays following an old Christian custom. This hearty soup sustained Finnish soldiers and became a national tradition.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Konstan M√∂lj√§ (family-run tavern in Kamppi), military-style buffets, traditional restaurants on Thursdays

hero_dishes.name: Graavilohi (Cured Salmon)
hero_dishes.description: Fresh salmon cured with salt, sugar, and dill, developing delicate balanced flavors over several days
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Scandinavian preservation technique that transforms raw fish into something sublime. The curing process was essential before refrigeration.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Old Market Hall, Restaurant Savoy (Alvar Aalto-designed 1937 classic), Kuurna bistro

signature_drinks.name: Kahvi (Finnish Coffee)
signature_drinks.description: Traditional filter coffee - Finland drinks more coffee per capita than any other country in the world
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Strong, black, and constantly. Finns drink it during kahvitauko (coffee break) with pulla (cardamom buns). Coffee culture is so important that business negotiations often happen over endless cups.

signature_drinks.name: Gl√∂gi
signature_drinks.description: Finnish mulled wine spiced with cinnamon, cloves, and cardamom, served with almonds and raisins
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Essential during winter darkness and Christmas markets. Locals drink it steaming hot while ice skating or visiting holiday markets.

signature_drinks.name: Lonkero (Long Drink)
signature_drinks.description: Finland's beloved gin and grapefruit soda cocktail invented for the 1952 Helsinki Olympics
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Refreshing summer drink enjoyed at terraces and after sauna. Available everywhere from corner shops to upscale bars.

food_culture_notes: Reservations are essential - Finns always book tables in advance, even for casual dining
The food scene emphasizes locally produced, organic ingredients and social responsibility
Sauna culture intersects with food culture - many restaurants have their own saunas (like L√∂yly)
Ruisleip√§ (rye bread) is sacred - dark, dense, slightly sour, eaten with every meal
Nordic minimalist presentation - simple, beautiful, letting ingredients shine
Foraging culture is huge - wild mushrooms, berries, herbs feature prominently in modern Finnish cuisine
Sunday dinner (sunnuntaip√§iv√§llinen) is family time, often featuring a roast
Pulla (cardamom-spiced sweet bun) with coffee is a daily ritual, not just a treat
